As a CEO I could appoint my wife a consultant and award her a large bonus effectively increasing my bonus. The salary they were requesting was far above what the employer was prepared to pay. So they sign a contract that says he gets X amount in salary and the balance in bonus only if he produces what he said he could. Thats a contract. The way it works in the real world is that the Bd of directors declare a bonus and the CEO gives each dept head X amount of dollars including his own bonus to distribute to his people as he sees fit. The dept head then deducts his and decides on an individual basis how to divide the balance. This leave room for kickbacks and dissention within the depts. Cash Bonuses are really not a good Idea IMO there are other methods to reward employees.

content: I have no objections to truly performance based bonuses, whether the CEO wants to award an across-the-board bonus based on overall company performance, or whether they select specific people and reward them for specific achievements (beating sales margin, or always making fresh coffee). I do not even mind if someone gets a majority of their income that way (that's what waiters do!) PROVIDED IT IS PERFORMANCE BASED. The problems here are that people were getting bonuses with nonexistant or marginal performance requirements. The overall problem is that these people were unwatched and overpaid.

content: Interesting replys,Except the concept is exactly the same. Putting your life on the line for your country is every every ones responsibility and duty. Same could be said for the Police, fire fighters,Iron workers,secret service,FBI, and anyone who has a hazardous job. Fact is we are a nation of laws that were meant to be adjudicated equally. Once exceptions are made were does it stop. If laws are wrong ammend them spell out all the exceptions lest they become precedents and used in different scienerios in the future. In AIGs case although morally wrong IMO is legal and the fault lies with our Government incompetants who wrote the agreements in the Bail out bills not spelling out how the money could be used. In fact AIG when compared to the military was at a disadvantage considering options. They could not retain critical personel with out large retention bonuses, wheras conscription would have filled all vacancys. The military has far more options that they chose not to use other than the retention bonuses. Conscription has a wide berth with a catch phrase For the good of service to retain and release.
